source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: Thermal creep rate decreases with time (has a primary and a steady-state part) and depends on temperature according to an Arrhenius law.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: The stress dependency of steady-state creep can be expressed by the so-called strain rate sensitivity $n = d l n$ (creep rate)/dln(stress). n was expected to be a constant, at least over significant ranges of stress, but instead was found to increase continuously with stress level [9].

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: Texture leads only to a moderate creep anisotropy.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: However, creep differs if tested under tension and compression (the so-called creep strength differential).

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: Irradiation-induced creep was found to depend mostly on fast neutron flux and stress as shown in Fig. 2.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: The influence of temperature is very small [5,6].

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: From Fig. 2 it can be deduced that creep is faster under tensile than under compressive conditions as in the case of thermal creep.

evidence_span: Furthermore, it can be seen that there is a stress-free diameter decrease due to superimposed irradiation growth, that is, shrinkage perpendicular to the tube axis (the volume of the material stays constant).

evidence_span: Figure 3 shows the state of knowledge in 1978 with regard to the temperature dependency [5].

evidence_span: Figure 4 gives the diameter decrease versus the reciprocal midwall temperature of experimental PWR fuel rods for claddings with different Sn content measured after an exposure of about 300 days.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: The figure reveals the large influence of the Sn content on in-reactor creep.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: In addition, it indicates that the creep rate increases with temperature in the temperature range of PWR fuel rod operation only if Sn is low. Otherwise, it even decreases slightly with increasing temperature.

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: The effectiveness of a single step at (constant) temperature T_i (K) during a timespan t_i (h) is given through k·t_i·exp( - T_A / T_i ) with T_A = 3254 K The "rate factor" k is arbitrarily chosen as k = 1E14 (h⁻¹) An accumulated particle growth parameter PGP after i annealing steps is then defined by PGP = Σ_i k·t_i·exp( - T_A / T_i )

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: The effectiveness of the initial quenching process from β- to α-phase can be approximately considered by adding the quotient 0.45/CDR to this sum, where CDR means the cooling down rate in the α phase in K/s

source_id: STP1295-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_11th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: For in-reactor corrosion, it has been shown that the size distribution of the intermetallics can be influenced by the fast neutron flux through the acceleration of dissolution processes as well as through the acceleration of foreign atom diffusion within the Zr lattice. At BWR operating temperature, the dissolution of initially fine intermetallics may be the reason for the increase of the corrosion rate at burnups in excess of about 20 MWd/kgU.
